title: Derivative Rules:
text:
Contant Rule: Taking the derivative of a constant is \(0\)
\[
f(x) = c
\] \[
f'(x) = 0
\]
Power Rule: \[
f(x) = x^{n}
\] \[
f'(x) = nx^{n-1}
\]
Sum & Difference Rules: Taking the derivative of the sum or difference of \(g(x)\) and \(f(x)\) is the same as the derivative of \(g(x)\) plus or minus the derivative of \(f(x)\) \[
\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(f(x) \pm g(x))
\text{ } = \text{ }
\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(f(x)) \pm \frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(g(x))
\]
Constant Multiple Rules: Taking the derivative of a constant times a derivative is the same as the constant multiplied by the derivative \[
\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(kf(c))
\text{ } = \text{ }
k\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(f(x))
\]
Product Rule: Taking the derivative of a function times a function \[
\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}}(f(x)g(x))
\text{ } = \text{ }
f'(x)g(x) + g'(x)f(x)
\]
Quotient Rule: Taking the derivative of a function divided by a function \[
\frac{\text{d}}{\text{dx}} \left(\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right)
\text{ } = \text{ }
\frac{f'(x)g(x)-g'(x)f(x)}{(g(x))^{2}}
\]
Chain Rule: to allow us to differentiate composite funtions
\[h(x) = (f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x))\] \[h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\]
Chain Rule with a Polynomial Function: \[
h(x) = (g(x))^{n}
\] \[
h'(x) = n(g(x))^{n-1}g'(x)
\]

title: Calc Notes
section: What is the Chain Rule used for?
text:
What is the Chain Rule used for?

to allow us to differentiate composite funtions

title: Derivative Rules:
text:
In Latex:
Double $$ is used for displaying math in the middle of the page in it’s own peditsool. I think that is best used for displaying equations. Maybe it can be used to show the steps of multiple equations
It also allows you to view the code output. Single $ is for inline math and I think this should be used most of the time.

title: calculus1_eaquinto
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
Intresting paradigm. Employers want experience. Graduate schools want grades. Competing interests… But they both ultimately want money.
What’s the point of education? Portfolio projects or mastery of subject?

section: An Open Letter to Graduate Schools:
text:
